Learning German - Universität Regensburg Learning German - Universität Regensburg UR Home Exchange Students News Application Accommodation Formalities Erasmus Formalities Learning German Courses and Course Selection Arrival Information Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Learning German German Language Courses Universität Regensburg offers a large variety of German language courses during the semester for students who wish to improve their German language skills. These courses are free of charge for exchange students and are offered on all language levels up to C2. On the basis of a placement test during the orientation course, students know which language level is best for them. This placement test is without any costs for exchange students. Students register for their language courses during the orientation programme. Detailed information on our German language courses The Pre-semester Intensive Language Training Course Universität Regensburg offers a pre-semester intensive language course for exchange students with little exposure to German (Level A1 to B1+). The course takes place 5-6 weeks before the semester starts (= beginning of March and beginning of September). Student assistants will support and advise the participants during the entire programme and help them get organised (including all formalities). Students will be credited with 14-18 ECTS for the regular and successful attendance of the course which covers approx. 160-180 hours of instruction. The course fee for participants in the ERASMUS programme is currently ?270; the fee for participants of other exchange programmes is ? 400. The fee includes tuition, orientation, and extra-curricular activities. However, costs for accommodation and other living expenses during the programme are not covered. Students from some partner institutions (especially those coming from less developed countries) are eligible for a language course scholarship offered by UR. If you are unsure whether you can obtain such a scholarship, please contact the International Office. Please note: This course should be attended by every student that has German knowledge below B2 level. The supporting programme and the orientation phase of the language course will be in German and English. Even though the course will be very intensive, students arriving with an A1/A2 level will in all not be able to successfully attend (German-taught) lectures. Therefore, we urgently recommend that these students take further German classes during the semester period. Students with a language performance on a good intermediate level (B2 or higher) should participate in the regular orientation programm in April/October. Application form (pdf-download) Christine Betzner - 05.06.2014 11:17 UR International Exchange Students - Coordinator Susanne Gschnaidner CONTACT Academic Calendar Course Catalogue Courses in English ? Información en español

Life in Regensburg - Universität Regensburg Life in Regensburg - Universität Regensburg UR Home Exchange Students News Application Accommodation Formalities Erasmus Formalities Learning German Courses and Course Selection Arrival Information Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Life in Regensburg UR international Universität Regensburg offers a well-organised social network between the International Office (IO), the Student Services Office, and the City of Regensburg; a free orientation programme for new international students; a broad offer of German language courses including preparatory language courses; student assistants who help you during your first days in Regensburg with all the necessary formalities; support with your search for accommodation; many activities such as excursions, get together parties, international coffee hours, which help you to find friends and get acquainted with Regensburg very quickly; and last but not least: Regensburg is a very safe place to be! Before you arrive in Germany you will most likely have many questions concerning living in Regensburg: Am I allowed to work while I study and how many hours may I work? Do I require a work permit? Do I have to open a bank account in Regensburg? How do I use the library and the computer centre? What do I do when I am ill? Or how can I make friends? and many other questions Our section "Life in Regensburg" provides you with all necessary information. Excursions - Universität Regensburg Excursions - Universität Regensburg UR Home Get Together News Events Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students International Day Excursions Tutor International Excursions Trip to the castles of Neuschwanstein and Hohenschwangau Visiting the castle Neuschwanstein should not be missed during one?s stay in Germany. The most well know castle in Germany was constructed by the Bavarian King Ludwig II in 1869. It was modeled after a night?s castle and dedicated to Richard Wagner. Since then, the impressive architecture with its splendidly furnished interiors and the breathtaking view of Allgäu draws millions of visitors per year. After a tour through this famous building we go directly across to the castle Hohenschwangau, where Ludwig II spent many happy days during his youth. In this Gothic style castle the furnishings have been preserved from the Biedermeier period. This can be seen especially in the banquet hall, which is rather impressive and occupies the entire width of the castle. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Trip to Christkindlesmarkt in Nuremberg During the Advent season one must go, at least once, to the Nürnberg Christmas market. Nowhere is the atmosphere nicer, the gingerbread taste better, nor the mulled wine warmer. Before we jump in to the pre-Christmas bustle we learn about historic Nürnberg through a city tour. It is a great opportunity to explore a medieval city in a pre-Christmas atmosphere while at the same time spending an afternoon with nice people at the Christmas market. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Trip to the Alte Pinakothek in Munich The Alte Pinakothek is one of the oldest galleries in the world and houses one of the most famous collections of Old Masters paintings. About 700 paintings of European Art from the 14th to the 18th centuries are exhibited in the Alte Pinakothek. Some of them - including the works of Albrecht Dürer, Peter Paul Rubens and Leonardo da Vinci - are among the highlights of the art. After visiting the museum we also have the opportunity to learn the history of the city of Munich with a guided tour. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Trip to Berlin This 5-day trip takes us to the German capital, Berlin! The program includes a sightseeing tour through Berlin, a visit to the Bundestag, and a trip to Potsdam with a tour of the castle Sanssouci. There is also plenty of free time to explore more of the vibrant city, as well as enjoy its electric nightlife. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Trip to Walhalla on 05.04.2014 A boat trip down the Danube leads us to one of the most recognizable structures in the Regensburg region. Walhalla is considered the masterpiece of all the artistic creations of the Bavarian King Ludwig I. Walhalla was built by the architect Leo von Klenze from the year 1830 to 1842. The steps of the monument provide a great view over the Danube and surrounding region, while the interior of the monument honors ?big heads?: 128 marble busts and 64 plaques attest to German and European history, the benchmarks of the humanities, natural science, literature, music, and the visual arts. After the tour the boat brings us back to Regensburg. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Trip to the castles of Neuschwanstein and Linderhof on 26.04.2014 Visiting the castle Neuschwanstein should not be missed during one?s stay in Germany. The most well know castle in Germany was constructed by the Bavarian King Ludwig II in 1869. It was modeled after a night?s castle and dedicated to Richard Wagner. Since then, the impressive architecture with its splendidly furnished interiors and the breathtaking view of Allgäu draws millions of visitors per year. After a tour of this famous building we continue to Linderhof, which is the smallest of the castles of Ludwig II. Apart from the sumptuous rooms of the royal summer residence, we will also visit the parks and the grotto, that was specially built by Ludwig II for the production of the play the "Ring of the Nibelung" by Richard Wagner. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Trip to Weltenburg Abbey and Hall of Liberation Kelheim on 21.06.2014 The Weltenburg Abbey is a Benedictine monastery near Kelheim on the Danube. The monastery, founded by Irish or Scottish monks in about 620, is held to be the oldest monastery in Bavaria and Weltenburg Abbey brewery is by some reckonings the oldest monastery brewery in the world, having been in operation since 1050. There we will have a white sausage breakfast surrounded by the Baroque monastery complex in one of the most beautiful beer gardens in Bavaria. Then we go by boat through the Danube Gorge to Kelheim. From there a small path leads up to the Hall of Liberation built by Ludwig I 1863. This memorial is not only an imposing structure, but it also offers a breathtaking view over the Danube and Altmühltal. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Trip to castle Herrenchiemsee and to Burghausen 24.05.2014 The excursion takes us first to Burghausen. The Burghausen Castle is of the largest castles in Germany. The grounds of the castle are accessible throughout the year. After the castle tour we travel to Prien at Chiemsee. On Herreninsel (an island), situated in the middle of the lake, the Herrenchiemsee castle attracts thousands of visitors. Also we go by boat to the island and then visit the castle, that King Ludwig II had built following the example of Versailles. Registration required: aaa.fahrten@ur.de Tanja Yakovleva - 16.05.2014 13:37 UNIVERSITÄT Get together Social Activities, Excursions International Coffee Hours: When: Tue + Thu 1.00 - 2.30 pm Where: International Office (room 18a)

Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students - Universität Regensburg

Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students - Universität Regensburg Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students - Universität Regensburg UR Home Get Together News Events Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students International Day Excursions Tutor International Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students Universität Regensburg welcomes you and your family. Our advisor team in the International Office will help as best as possible. Our Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and PhD Candidates will help you with regards to all questions concerning administrative tasks, finding accommodation and other questions concerning your everyday life. The Welcome Center also offers excursions and activities especially conceived for international researchers (including PhD students) as well as for their families. Get Together - Universität Regensburg Get Together - Universität Regensburg UR Home Get Together News Events Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students International Day Excursions Tutor International Get Together Dear students of Universität Regensburg, We would like invite you for our "Get Together"-Program! Our aims: promote the contact between foreign and German students. familiarize our international students with Regensburg, the area and of course with the land and the people. promote the understanding between cultures and people. We offer: Consultaion, support, orientation, integration International Coffee Hour every Tuesday and Thursday from 1 to 2:30 pm Guided tours at the university and in our city Welcome Party in the winter semester International Day in the summer semester Excursions and trips in Bavaria and Germany Cooperation with other organisations like Tutor International, ISNR (International Students Network Regensburg) and the fraternities ESG and KHG. International Day - Universität Regensburg International Day - Universität Regensburg UR Home Get Together News Events Guest Researchers and Doctoral Students International Day Excursions Tutor International International Day International Day at UR Every summer the International Office organizes an International Day on campus. All international students have the opportunity to present their home countries and home institutions. This is a great opportunity for them to meet other students and exchange experiences. Since 2010, we have included our Regensburg students (who have just completed a semester studying abroad) in the event. The Regensburg students participate very actively during the International Day. Late morning there is a student fair with stands about the different countries and exchange possibilities. For the International Day 2012, more than 30 different countries were represented by German and international students. The student fair helps students who are interested in spending some time abroad to meet former exchange students and exchange "first-hand information". In the evening the International Office invites all new international students as well as all German students who have just returned from their study abroad to a Bavarian dinner. Highlights 2012 The European exchange programme ERASMUS celebrated its 25th birthday! 25 years of successful study abroad experiences! (Photo: Klaudia Wodniok) "Where is Mickiewicz?" Another event included in the International Day was a photo exhibition from a former ERASMUS-student: Ms. Barbara Standke, an art student, who spent an ERASMUS-stay at the University of Torun in Poland during 2010/11. Her photo exhibition presented pictures taken during her time in Torun. Ms. Barbara Standke (middle) with Ms. Grotz, ERASMUS-Coordinator and Ms. Betzner, Organization International Day. (Photo: Christine Betzner, IO) Christine Betzner - 29.01.2013 15:10 UNIVERSITÄT Get together Social Activities, Excursions International Coffee Hours: When: Tue + Thu 1.00 - 2.30 pm Where: International Office (room 18a)

Short Term Accommodation Student Residences Startklar ? Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Accommodation Finding accommodation certainly is one of the most important topics for all new international students. Although Regensburg has many student residences and many private student rooms, it is always difficult to find an inexpensive accommodation when you are new in a city. The International Office helps you to find a room with lists of useful addresses. Revision broadcast fee from 2013 - information for tenants The new broadcasting law comes into effect on January 1st 2013. The broadcasting fees will be replaced by a contribution and thus the GEZ (collection centre for radio and television licence fees) will be renamed into "ARD ZDF Deutschlandradio Beitragsservice" (office for contribution to ARD ZDF Deutschlandradio). Every household will be charged with a flat rate of 17.98 EUR/ month for all technical devices that are able to receive the programs provided by public-law broadcasting service (ARD, ZDF etc.). The new regulation does not differentiate between the number of technical devices the household possesses or whether these devices are used to received the public-law programs. The contribution equals the current maximum fee, which means that nothing changes for those who have already registered a TV set. This contribution implies the usage in vehicles. The contribution is to be paid quarterly. more information Christine Betzner - 04.09.2013 11:11 UR International Accommodation Sigrid Baumann Information and advice on accommodation for international students Contact

Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Application / Admission / Registration How do you apply successfully for a study programme at UR? To become a student at UR you have to fulfill certain requirements: You need to have German language skills unless you apply for an English-taught master programme or a PhD programme You need to fulfill the academic requirements. On the following pages you'll find all necessary information about the application procedure, which documents you need, and which requirements you need to meet to be admitted to UR. Please read all the information carefully. In case you have any further questions, you are welcome to contact us at the International Office. Degree Courses at UR - Universität Regensburg

Degree Courses at UR - Universität Regensburg Degree Courses at UR - Universität Regensburg UR Home International Degree Seeking Students News Degree Programmes German Skills Application / Admission / Registration Visa and Residence Regulations Finances Health Services Arrival Information Accommodation Startklar ? Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Degree Courses at UR Which degrees are offered at UR? The bachelor and master degrees are modularised programmes of study, meaning that in order to achieve the bachelor and master degree, a fixed selection of modules must be successfully completed. Modules are study units consisting of lectures and seminars that are related in succession and content. In principle, the difference is between the basal modules of the stage I studies and the advanced modules of the stage II studies. The "European Credit Transfer System" (ECTS) has been introduced in the modulated courses of study. The workload for the completion of lectures and seminars, which consists of time in class and home study, is measured in "Credit Points". The examinations in the modularised subjects are taken concurrently with studies, and performance accomplished in the various modules replaces the intermediate examination and the final examination. The following degrees are offered at the University of Regensburg: Bachelor The Bachelor is the first academic degree, which generally can be finished after six semesters of academic study. Moreover, it is a first professional-qualifying degree. The six-semester (= 3 years) programme of study is composed of three to four semesters of basic studies (stage I studies) and two to three semesters of in-depth studies (stage II studies). There is a difference between the Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) and the Bachelor of Science (B. Sc). For the B.A., either one major and two minors or two majors are studied. For the B.Sc., the emphasis is on the study of one subject only. Bachelor Programmes: List of all Bachelor programmes offered at UR. Structure of Bachelor programmes: 1st year BASIC STUDIES / STAGE I- 2 majors or 2nd year 1 major and 2 minor subjects 3rd year ADVANCED STUDIES / STAGE II - 1 bachelor subject + other courses Bachelor's Thesis Master The Master course of study is a graduate degree programme that generally lasts four semesters. Prerequisite for acceptance into a Master programme is the completion of a Bachelor degree or an academic certificate of equal worth. Examination rules regulate which courses of study (majors) or Bachelor degrees will be approved as prerequisites for admission into the respective Master programme. Universität Regensburg offers the following Master degrees: Master of Arts (M.A.) Master of Science (M.Sc.) Magister Legum (LLM) - special program for international students Magister Theologiae (M.T.) Master Programmes: List of all Master programmes offered at UR. Information on the Magister Legum (LLM) Structure of Master programmes: 1st year COURSE OF STUDIES 2nd year COURSE OF STUDIES Master's Thesis English Taught Master Degree Programmes Universität Regensburg offers currently eight English-taught degree programmes on Master level (see list below). Master programmes in Chemistry, Mathematics and Nanoscience are partly taught in Englih. All Bachelor programmes are German taught programmes. American Studies British Studies English Linguistics European-American Studies (limited English taught course offer in Political Science) Experimental and Clinical Neurosciences (ECN) Complex Condensed Materials and Soft Matter (COSOM)* Physics Computational Physics Further information on our English taught degree programmes. State Examination For the "Staatsexamen", the state officially acts as the examiner. Upon its completion, one finishes the degree programme in medicine, law, pharmacy, and teaching. Depending on the subject, the standard period of study averages between eight and twelve semesters. The training and examinations are standardized statewide and nationwide. Training is concluded at the university with the first Staatexamen. For lawyers and teachers, the traineeship that takes place outside of the university is completed with a second Staatexamen. The following degree programmes end with a state examination: teacher training degree programmes medical studies pharmacy law Doctoral Studies Doctoral Studies The goal of graduate studies is the conferral of a doctoral degree. In contrast to many international degree systems, there usually is no formalized curriculum in Germany for doctoral studies. The doctoral course of study normally is based on individual research. The content of the doctoral programme is: participation in advanced lectures (advanced seminars, doctoral seminars, research seminars); collaboration with the advising faculty member ("Doktorvater"); in the natural sciences, collaboration with the research group of the advising faculty member; individual research work in the composition of the dissertation. The core piece of the doctorate is the dissertation ("Doktorarbeit"). After the acceptance of the dissertation, an oral defence ("Disputation") takes place. The degree of Doctor is first conferred after the dissertation has been published. The type and extent of the examination is regulated through the respective degree regulations. The doctoral study lasts normally three to four years. For further information please see our section on doctoral studies. Additional Qualifications UR students have several possibilities to receive additional qualifications while they study at UR. List of all additional programmes. (information only available in German) Christine Betzner - 03.07.2014 09:24 UR International International Degree Seeking Students Elli Wunderlich Term dates Application deadlines Scholarships FAQ ? Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Schedule Course Results Information and Advice Term Dates Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Term Dates The academic year is divided into two semesters: winter semester and summer semester. The winter semester begins 1 October and ends 31 March. The summer semester begins 1 April and ends 30 September. Only during part of the semester do courses take place. There are two long semester breaks when examinations take place and students write their seminar papers or do lab courses. --> Term dates for the upcoming semesters Christine Betzner - 23.01.2014 13:28 UR International International Degree Seeking Students Elli Wunderlich Term dates Application deadlines Scholarships FAQ ? Financial Aid - Universität Regensburg Financial Aid - Universität Regensburg UR Home International Degree Seeking Students News Degree Programmes German Skills Application / Admission / Registration Visa and Residence Regulations Finances Costs Work and Study Funding Health Services Arrival Information Accommodation Startklar ? Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Financial Aid Scholarships and Grants Unlike other countries, most German institutes of higher education have not introduced a students loan service nor do they offer any award scholarships. The largest scholarship organisation in Germany certainly is the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) in Bonn. However like all other grants from German scholarship organizations, these grants are announced and awarded partly in the home country of the applicant. You can obtain information about such scholarships from the German Embassy and from German cultural institutions in your home country, for example from the Goethe-Institutes or outposts of the DAAD. Some foundations accept international students who already are studying in Germany, but normally only advanced students-in some cases only graduate and postgraduate students-can apply for a scholarship. These stipends usually are awarded for a period of six months or a year, but sometimes an extension is possible. You can find an overview of grant-awarding organizations under: http://www.funding-guide.de https://www.study-in-bavaria.de/how/financing-your-studies/ Here are some organizations listed that offer grants for international students: Deutschlandstipendium - German Scholarhip for Students The German Federal Government has initiated a national scholarship programme called "Deutschlandstipendium" (http://www.deutschlandstipendium.de) to support specially gifted students of any nationality at German universities. This programme is co-financed by the German Ministry of Education and Research and private donors. The scholarship amounts to ? 300 per month and is awarded for the duration of at least one year. The Deutschland Stipendium is conceived in a way that private donors (either business, alumni or foundations) come up with half the amount (? 150), which is then paired with federal funds. The scholarships are awarded to highly motivated and performance-oriented students, who have excellent grades and who are expected to have a good performance during their studies and later on in the professional world. Other very important requisites are: extra-curricular engangement, willingness to assume social responsibility as well as special personal and family circumstances. The University Regensburg awarded the "Deutschlandstipendium" first time ever during the winter semester 2011/12 gifted students. The scholarship is awarded once a year during the winter semester. Deadline to apply for the Deutschlandstipendium is August 31, 2012. More information on the scholarship and application (in German) Bayhost - Yearly Post-Graduate Scholarships Bayhost - Yearly scholarship for university graduates from Bulgaria, Croatia Poland, Rumania, Serbia , Slovakia, Czech Republic, Ucraine and Hungary Well-founded specialized knowledge, the ability to work in an interdisciplinary environment and international exposure are considerable requirements that European scholars need to fulfill. A post-graduate study programme abroad can complement and deepen the skills you already gained during your undergraduate degree as well as be a great contribution to your personal development. Have you already decided to do a post-graduate programme in Bavaria? The Free State of Bavaria awards every year scholarships for univesity graduates that come from Eastern Europe. Supported are post-graduate programmes and dissertations. You may find more information about this scholarship and application forms in the following website: www.bayhost.de Deadline is December 1st! BayBIDS Scholarship for graduates of German Schools abroad --- AUF DEUTSCH --- Motivationsstipendium: jedes Semester vergibt BayBIDS Stipendien an Absolventen Deutscher Auslands- und Partnerschulen, die ein Studium in Bayern aufnehmen. Den Stipendiaten wird damit der Einstieg in ihr Studium erleichtert, gleichzeitig fungieren sie als Mentoren für interessierte Absolventen Deutscher Auslands- und Partnerschulen. Die Stipendien werden zunächst für eine Dauer von 6 Monaten vergeben (bis zu 2 Semester möglich), der monatliche Zuschuss beträgt 300 ?. Die Universität Regensburg kann pro Semester 1 Kandidaten/in für das Stipendium nominieren. Bitte, wenn Sie einen Abschluss von einer Deutschen Schule im Ausland erworben haben und an der UR eingeschrieben sind, kontaktieren Sie Frau Elli Wunderlich bis zu zwei Wochen nach Vorlesungsbeginn (30. Oktober oder 30. April). Voraussetzungen: Absolvent/in einer Deutschen Auslandsschule mit nichtdeutscher Staatsangehörigkeit Vorzugsweise Studienanfänger DS-Absolventen, die bereits ein DAAD-Vollstipendium erhalten, können nicht gefördert werden. Go West - Scholarship for European Master & Internship The Haniel Stiftung awards scholarships for qualified graduates (BA or MA) from middle or eastern European countries including Russia. Applicants should have graduated in Business Management, Economics or a related subject, and should do a European Master programme at a German university (duration: 1-2 years) and an internship at an international institution or enterprise. Deadline for applications: May 31 for the next academic year (starting in fall). Alfred Töpfer Scholarship Each year, the Alfred Töpfer Foundation F.V.S. provides students of the humanities and social sciences, but also of the fine and performing arts, architecture as well as agricultural and forestry sciences, up to 15 scholarships. The students should me from Europe (excluding Germany), Turkey and Israel and be matriculated at a German University. The scholarships amount to ?600 monthly for students and ?1.100 for PhD students. In scholarship holders receive a mobility grant of ? 200 per month. Deadline for submission: End of May of each year. www.toepfer-stiftung.de/fellowship-am-kolleg-europa.html BAföG - Student Loan & Grant BaföG Claims for the Bafög (a law on support for education and training) usually are reserved for German citizens. International students may file for the BaföG only in a few special cases, for example: if you have been granted asylum or have been accepted as a refugee; if one of your parents is German; if your spouse is German; if you have been employed for at least 5 years in Germany before the beginning of the degree programme; if one of your parents has been working in Germany for at least three of the last six years before the beginning of the degree programme. You can get additional information about the BaföG from the student services office of Niederbayern-Oberpfalz: Studentenwerk Niederbayern-Oberpfalz Amt für Ausbildungsförderung (Studentenhaus 2. Stock), Albertus-Magnus-Str. 4 93053 Regensburg Tel. (0941) 943-2209 Please inform yourself early (by all means before the beginning of studies) about the possibilities available! Student Grants for International Students in Financial Need UR offers financial support for international students in financial need. You can apply for such a small grant if you fulfil the following requirements: Nationality of non-EU member state and non-industrialized country! Bachelor/ Staatsexamen degree programmes: You must already have had completed at least two semesters in Regensburg. Master- degree programme: You already must have had completed at least one semester in Regensburg. As the number of applicants is very high, unfortunately not every applicant can be granted financial help. The funds are designated only for worthy students in need. The worthiness is to be proven through certificates (for example via the intermediate examination or ?Zwischenprüfung?) and a listing of proven academic achievements previously made (?Scheine?/FlexNow printout). The number of the proven academic achievements as well as the time frame in which the achievements were made must be consistent with the requirements of the rules and regulations of the University (?Prüfnungsordnung?). If an application for extension is made, only the latest proof of academic achievements is to be provided. The neediness of a student then is shown if the applicant does not possess his or her own means of funds and is not receiving adequate financial support from relatives or a spouse and or from a scholarship organization or another entity. A financial situation declaration in the application form is to be submitted by the applicant. This declaration is bound by law. The awarded educational assistance is to be repaid in the full amount should the applicant become a citizen of the Republic of Germany. The application will only then be processed if it is complete, i.e. if all questions are answered and all required documents are enclosed: Resume with photo (for first-time applicants) Proof of citizenship (copy of passport) Copy of certificates acquired List of grades (?Scheine?) and Flex/Now printout Proof of enrolment (?Immatrikuationsbescheinignung?) for the semester in which the assistance is being applied for Letter of reference from an instructor in the main field of study Bank statements from the past three months Important: Student grants cannot be awarded to guest students (for example visitors of German courses) or to students just beginning studies. Application deadline: normally at the end of the first week of classes. For further information, please contact the International Office. Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Financial Aid Scholarships and Grants Unlike other countries, most German institutes of higher education have not introduced a students loan service nor do they offer any award scholarships. The largest scholarship organisation in Germany certainly is the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) in Bonn. However like all other grants from German scholarship organizations, these grants are announced and awarded partly in the home country of the applicant. You can obtain information about such scholarships from the German Embassy and from German cultural institutions in your home country, for example from the Goethe-Institutes or outposts of the DAAD. Some foundations accept international students who already are studying in Germany, but normally only advanced students-in some cases only graduate and postgraduate students-can apply for a scholarship. These stipends usually are awarded for a period of six months or a year, but sometimes an extension is possible. You can find an overview of grant-awarding organizations under: http://www.funding-guide.de https://www.study-in-bavaria.de/how/financing-your-studies/ Here are some organizations listed that offer grants for international students: Deutschlandstipendium - German Scholarhip for Students The German Federal Government has initiated a national scholarship programme called "Deutschlandstipendium" (http://www.deutschlandstipendium.de) to support specially gifted students of any nationality at German universities. This programme is co-financed by the German Ministry of Education and Research and private donors. The scholarship amounts to ? 300 per month and is awarded for the duration of at least one year. The Deutschland Stipendium is conceived in a way that private donors (either business, alumni or foundations) come up with half the amount (? 150), which is then paired with federal funds. The scholarships are awarded to highly motivated and performance-oriented students, who have excellent grades and who are expected to have a good performance during their studies and later on in the professional world. Other very important requisites are: extra-curricular engangement, willingness to assume social responsibility as well as special personal and family circumstances. The University Regensburg awarded the "Deutschlandstipendium" first time ever during the winter semester 2011/12 gifted students. The scholarship is awarded once a year during the winter semester. Deadline to apply for the Deutschlandstipendium is August 31, 2012. More information on the scholarship and application (in German) Bayhost - Yearly Post-Graduate Scholarships Bayhost - Yearly scholarship for university graduates from Bulgaria, Croatia Poland, Rumania, Serbia , Slovakia, Czech Republic, Ucraine and Hungary Well-founded specialized knowledge, the ability to work in an interdisciplinary environment and international exposure are considerable requirements that European scholars need to fulfill. A post-graduate study programme abroad can complement and deepen the skills you already gained during your undergraduate degree as well as be a great contribution to your personal development. Have you already decided to do a post-graduate programme in Bavaria? The Free State of Bavaria awards every year scholarships for univesity graduates that come from Eastern Europe. Supported are post-graduate programmes and dissertations. You may find more information about this scholarship and application forms in the following website: www.bayhost.de Deadline is December 1st! Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Finances How do you finance your studies? Please take into consideration that is very difficult to finance your studies just by working during the semester breaks or during the semester. When you apply for your residence permit you have to prove that you have sufficient financial means for your studies e.g. by showing saving accounts or through financial support from your parents. Studying in Germany is expensive, even though living expenses in Regensburg are still quite moderate. You will need money for rent, food, tuition, and books as well as for social activities and travelling. German Skills - Universität Regensburg German Skills - Universität Regensburg UR Home International Degree Seeking Students News Degree Programmes German Skills DSH exam Preparatory language courses Regular Courses Application / Admission / Registration Visa and Residence Regulations Finances Health Services Arrival Information Accommodation Startklar ? Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact German Skills How well should you know German to study at UR? A good command of the German language is essential, as the lectures in almost all of the degree programmes at the University of Regensburg are held in German (with the exception of a few graduate colleges and English taught master programmes).Therefore, you should have sufficient German language skills on intermediate level if you apply for a regular Bachelor programme or Master programme. Our international applicants have to pass a German language test (the DSH = Sprachprüfung für den Hochschulzugang ausländischer Studienbewerber?) before they can enrol. This test must be passed on either level DSH-2 or DSH-3. Applicants without proficiency in the German language will not be granted admission to a degree programme unless it is an English taught Master programme or a doctoral programme (see explanation below) Please note: Applicants for the Bachelor of Science in Chemistry, the Master of Science in Chemistry, and the Master of Science in Medicinal Chemistry only need to have passed the test with DSH 1. Doctoral students who have the permission to write their doctoral thesis in a foreign language as well as students in an English-taught Master programme are exempt from this language entry requirement. Preparatory language courses Universität Regensburg offers preparatory language courses for those, whose German is below level C1. Applicants for Human Medicine, Dental Medicine, and Pharmacy cannot apply for a preparatory language course at UR. UR has only a very limited number of places available within these three degree programmes, therefore applicants do not only have to have excellent grades but also very good German langauge skills in order to receive a place. Who is exempt from the DSH? You may be exempt from the DSH if: you have already passed the DSH at onother university, you have passed an equivalent language test to the DSH (information about equivalent exams) you are a Ph.D. candidate with departmental permission to write your dissertation in a foreign language you are applying for an English-taught master programme. The department of German as a Foreign Language provides information on the DSH. (German version only) Christine Betzner - 17.05.2013 09:22 UR International International Degree Seeking Students Elli Wunderlich Term dates Application deadlines Scholarships FAQ ? CONTACT

Health Insurance - Universität Regensburg Health Insurance - Universität Regensburg UR Home International Degree Seeking Students News Degree Programmes German Skills Application / Admission / Registration Visa and Residence Regulations Finances Health Services Health Insurance Seeing a Doctor Arrival Information Accommodation Startklar ? Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Health Insurance For several reasons you absolutely must have valid health insurance in Germany: There are no medical facilities that are free of charge for students. If you get sick, you must go to a doctor in the city or in a hospital. Students must have health insurance because without proof of health insurance, the University is unable to accept enrolment or re-registration (Rückmeldung). The law stipulates membership in a statutory health insurance fund. Statutory Health Insurances German law stipulates that in order to grant foreigners in Germany a residence permit, sufficient health insurance for the duration of their stay in Germany must be proven. Normally, this proof is furnished with the certificate of statutory insurance in Germany. Statuatory health insurance funds are, for example: Techniker Krankenkasse (TK), Deutsche Angestellten-Krankenkasse (DAK), Barmer Ersatzkasse, AOK. Some countries (all EU countries, Bulgaria and Romania as of 1.1.2007, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Liechtenstein, Macedonia, Norway, Sweden, Serbia, Montenegro, Tunisia, and Turkey) have a social insurance agreement (Sozialversicherungsabkommen) with Germany. For members of these countries, insurance is not compulsory; however, these members must have the exemption from the compulsory insurance confirmed by a German statutory insurance fund and submit this confirmation upon enrolment. The Techniker Krankenkasse (one of the statutory health insurance) has its own service point for students on campus:Josef-Engert-Str. 11, 93053 Regensburg, Tel: 0941/40 96 206 If you come from Bosnia-Herzegowina, Croatia, Mazedonia, Serbia and Montenegro, Tunesia or Turkey, we recommend a statutory health insurance here in Germany as these countries have social insurance agreements that offer only a very limited coverage for an emergency. If you are not from a country with the social insurance agreement, you must take out statutory health insurance in Germany. Addresses of the health insurances you get during the orientational programme ?Startklar? or in the Academic Exchange Office. Private Health Insurances If you are over 30 years old, you cannot get insurance at the student rate. In this case, you need private health insurance. You can obtain information about private health insurance recognized by the Ausländerbehörde in Regensburg from Ms. Wunderlich at the International Office (AAA). PLEASE NOTE: There are special rules regarding health insurance for the students who participate in a preparatory German language course at the University of Regensburg. Please let Ms. Wunderlich advise you about this. Christine Betzner - 20.11.2012 11:54 UR International International Degree Seeking Students Elli Wunderlich Term dates Application deadlines Scholarships FAQ ? CONTACT

Seeing a Doctor - Universität Regensburg Seeing a Doctor - Universität Regensburg UR Home International Degree Seeking Students News Degree Programmes German Skills Application / Admission / Registration Visa and Residence Regulations Finances Health Services Health Insurance Seeing a Doctor Arrival Information Accommodation Startklar ? Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Seeing a Doctor For emergencies (if you cannot go to the doctor on your own), dial 112 for emergency medical services. Where can you find a doctor? If you need to see a doctor during the day you need to see your general practitioner. If you have not yet been to a doctor in Regensburg, you will find a list in the phone book under the letter ?A' (Ärzte). If you need a doctor outside the regular office hours, you can call the following number; "Ärztlicher Bereitschaftsdienst", Tel. 01805- 19 12 12 (valid for Regensburg). Since mid-April you may also call 116 117, which is valid all over Germany. If you urgently need a dentist on weekends, public holidays or during the night, you can call the "Zahnärztliche Notdienst im Universitätsklinikum" (Dental Emergency Service at the University Hospital), Tel. (0941) 944-0 What do you need to bring? Students insured via the social security agreement need to bring their European Health Insurance Card (EHIC). (You can get this from your insurance company in your home country). Students who have taken out public health insurance in Germany need to bring the insurance card they received from that insurance company. Students with private insurance need to bring corresponding proof of their insurance. Orientation Programme Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Life in Regensburg UR International Before you arrive in Germany you will most likely have many questions concerning living in Regensburg: Am I allowed to work while I study and how many hours may I work? Do I require a work permit? Do I have to open a bank account in Regensburg? How do I use the library and the computer centre? What do I do when I am ill? Or how can I make friends? and many other questions. Our section "Life in Regensburg" provides you with all necessary information. Universität Regensburg offers a well-organised social network between the International Office (IO), the Student Services Office, and the City of Regensburg a free orientation programme for new international students. a broad offer of German language courses including preparatory language courses student assistants who help you during your first days in Regensburg with all the necessary formalities support with your search for accommodation many activities such as excursions, get-together parties, international coffee hours, which help you to find friends and get acquainted with Regensburg very quickly and last but not least: Regensburg is a very safe place to be! Orientation Programme - Universität Regensburg UR Home International Degree Seeking Students News Degree Programmes German Skills Application / Admission / Registration Visa and Residence Regulations Finances Health Services Arrival Information Accommodation Startklar ? Orientation Programme Startklar Team Schedule Comments Useful links Organizing Your Studies Life in Regensburg FAQ Download Contact Startklar ? Orientation Programme This programme is financed by your student fees. What does "Startklar" stand for? Startklar is an orientation programme free of charge for new international students. Content and Organisation During the programme you will receive all necessary information and help you need for completing the formalities at the beginning of your studies e.g. opening a bank account, getting health insurance, getting your student ID, visa regulations. The programme includes tours through the library, the computer labs, several campus tours, extra-curricular activities as well as guided tours through the city. Registration Together with your letter of admission you will receive a registration form for "Startklar". This form needs to be handed in either directly at the Studentenkanzlei (the Office of the Registrar) or at the International Office (Ms Wunderlich). Internationalisation - Universität Regensburg Internationalisation - Universität Regensburg UR Home Internationalisation Guideline Internationalisation UR international The University of Regensburg offers a cosmopolitan and hospitable environment with an outstanding teaching and research quality. UR has partnerships with approx. 240 partner institutions worldwide in Europe, Overseas, Asia and Australia. About 1.300 international students are currently enrolled from almost 100 different nations. Guest researches and PhD candidates Our Welcome Center offers help to new international guest researchers and PhD candidates in several areas, including information on visa requirements, accommodation, formalities and insurances. We also offer support if you are considering to come to the UR with family, for example tips for your partner on where to take German classes, or where to find appropriate child care and/or schooling options. International Degree Programs Double Degree programs, English taught Master programs as well as degree programs with a strong international focus enhance the international profile of UR. The International Office is the point of contact for all questions concerning your stay at Universität Regensburg. Whether coming for one or two semesters, for a whole degree, or for a research stay, we will provide you with information and advice on a comprehensive array of topics. For further information please refer to our German pages. Christine Betzner - 18.06.2014 09:18 UNIVERSITÄT Internationalisation Marianne Sedlmeier Head of International Office Contact

Life in Regensburg - Universität Regensburg Life in Regensburg - Universität Regensburg UR Home Life in Regensburg Student Life Service for Guest Researchers Working Money Food Library Computer Services Religion Sports Culture Public Transportation Seeing a Doctor Accommodation Contact Life in Regensburg Why Universität Regensburg? Check it out yourself! Click on the film to get a first impression of our campus university. The video could not be loaded. Please click here to open the video in the media center. Interested? Here you will find other image films: "Treffpunkt der Welt" "Ich liebe die Uni Regensburg" What you need to know about the UR The University of Regensburg is a modern campus University situated at the southeast edge of the old historic town of Regensburg. It is a modern research-oriented university founded in 1962 and includes 11 faculties with more than 100 study programmes at bachelor, master and PhD level. The attractiveness of the university in enhanced by the appeal of the city itself, with its ever-present traces of more than 2,000 years of history. Since July 2006, Regensburg carries the UNESCO distinction "World Heritage", which recognizes the unique character of the medieval city centre and its magnificent architecture - above all the Old Stone Bridge above the Danube and St. Peter's Cathedral. About 20,000 students are currently enrolled at UR (as for winter semester 2011/2012) including an international student community of approx. 1,400 students). New in Regensburg? -- Get Together-Programme If this is your first time in Regensburg, you'll probably have many questions about life in Regensburg. Needless to say you'll be interested in practical matters, such as where to eat while at the university, how to open a bank account, what type of medical facilities exist or how long is the library open. The International Office offers an orientation programme to help new international students get acquanted with Regensburg. In addition there is also a Get together-Programm with an international Coffee Hour, excursions in Regensburg and in the surroundings as well other activities. Our programm is designed to help you to make friends in an easy and fast way, and to feel comfortable at our university. You have come to Regensburg as a Visiting Researcher? The Welcome Center offers help to new international guest researchers and PhD candidates in several areas, including information on visa requirements, accommodation, formalities and insurances. We also offer support if you are considering to come to the UR with family, for example tips for your partner on where to take German classes, or where to find appropriate child care and/or schooling options. We have also put valuable information together for PhD candidates wishing to enrol at the UR. ? Guest Researchers ? International Doctoral Candidates You may also find useful tips about how to settle in Regensburg or Bavaria in the following website: study-in-bavaria.de Christine Betzner - 22.01.2014 12:18 UR International Life in Regensburg ? Intern. Students ? Exchange Student ? Welcome Center for Guest Researchers and PhD Students

Computer Services - Universität Regensburg Computer Services - Universität Regensburg UR Home Life in Regensburg Student Life Service for Guest Researchers Working Money Food Library Computer Services Religion Sports Culture Public Transportation Seeing a Doctor Accommodation Contact Computer Services Using the Computer Services UR has an excellent computer centre with more than 30 computer pool (CIP-pools) which can be used for free by students and guest researchers. Students receive with their enrolment automatically an e-mail address and an informational sheet with directions on how to use their RZ account. Guest researchers should contact their academic hosts to receive their free computer account or the Welcome Center. In order to use the printers, you have to purchase pre-paid printing cards (with values of 2, 5, 10 or 20 Euro) available in the cafeterias, the Edeka supermarket shop, the stationary shop Igeko and at the kiosk in the ?Klinikum? (can also be paid for with the MensaCard). Scanners are located in the main library building. You can use the colour printers of the ?Rechenzentrum? via the computers in all computer pools. Christine Betzner - 10.02.2014 15:49 UR International Life in Regensburg ? Intern. Students ? Exchange Student ? Welcome Center for Guest Researchers and PhD Students

Money - Universität Regensburg Money - Universität Regensburg UR Home Life in Regensburg Student Life Service for Guest Researchers Working Money Food Library Computer Services Religion Sports Culture Public Transportation Seeing a Doctor Accommodation Contact Money Bank Account It is absolutely necessary to have a German bank account when you live in Regensburg for a longer time. Rents, insurances etc. are paid through an account. Please remember that to take care of all your expenses you need to open a ?Girokonto? (checking / current account). Which documents do you need to open a bank account? International students will need the following documents in order to open an account: your passport. your student ID (at some banks, students do not need to pay bank charges) International guest researcher should bring a copy of their work contract or a letter from their German advisor plus their passport. Studying in Regensburg - How much money do you need for your living expenses? Two financial components have to be considered when planning your studies in Germany: Tuition/semester fees and Cost of living Tuition Tuition Fees at Bavarian universities revoked Effective on October 1, 2013 Bavarian universities will be charging no tuition fees. Therefore students will not need to pay tuition for the winter semester 2013/14 . To re-register you will still need to pay the student service fee however, which includes the semester transportation ticket (? 117 summer semester 2014). More details on tuition fees, procedures, etc. are available here (only in German!). The following links will inform you of the exact rules of the Bavarian university laws and the corresponding legal regulations of the University of Regensburg: website of the Bavarian Ministry of Science http://www.uni-regensburg.de ?Rechtsgrundlagen?Studienbeitragssatzung der Universität Regensburg http://www.uni-regensburg.de ? Studentenkanzlei Living Expenses Cost of Living To receive a residence permit to study at the University of Regensburg, you must demonstrate to the Municipal Immigration Office (Ausländerbehörde) that you have enough money available to live in Germany. As a general orientation, at least ? 600,- per month would be accepted as proof that you have sufficient means to support yourself. Each month you should count on the following fixed costs: Rent: approximately ? 150,- to ? 250,- Health Insurance: approximately ? 80,- Broadcasting fee: approx. 18,- Euro per month. For a meal in the cafeteria at the University you pay around ? 4,-. Each semester you should reckon on expenditures amounting to approximately ?150, - to ? 350, - for materials for your studies (books, etc). Each semester at the University, you additionally must pay student service fee (Studentenwerksbeitrag) in the amount of ? 117,- (summer semester 2014). The student service fee serves as a "semester ticket" with which you can ride the buses and trains in Regensburg and within a radius of about 50 km without extra costs. The University of Regensburg assumes that international students can bear all costs themselves. When applying, you confirm in a financial declaration (Finanzierungserklärung ) that you have the necessary funds available. The financial declaration also is a requirement (for non-EU citizens) to be issued a residence permit for studying. Christine Betzner - 19.11.2013 09:31 UR International Life in Regensburg ? Intern. Students ? Exchange Student ? Welcome Center for Guest Researchers and PhD Students

Seeing a Doctor - Universität Regensburg Seeing a Doctor - Universität Regensburg UR Home Life in Regensburg Student Life Service for Guest Researchers Working Money Food Library Computer Services Religion Sports Culture Public Transportation Seeing a Doctor Accommodation Contact Seeing a Doctor Where do you find a doctor? If you get sick during the day please contact your general practitioner. To find a doctor check the phone book for the list of addresses (look under the letter ?A ? Ärzte?). Many doctor?s offices are closed on Wednesday and Friday afternoons. On weekends and bank holidays as well as nights, please call the following number: 01805-19 12 12 (only valid for Regensburg). You will receive the address and phone number of a doctor on duty. Since mid-April you may also use the following number 116 117, which is valid all over Germany. For dentists on duty, please contact the dental clinic: (0941) 944-0. You will find a list of all emergency numbers below. Which documents do you have to present? Always carry your insurance card with you. Students who are insured through the European Insurance Agreement (EHIC) receive their card from the insurance in their home country. Photo: Johannes Gilger (CC BY-SA 2.0) Christine Betzner - 15.01.2013 14:13 UR International Life in Regensburg ? Intern. Students ? Exchange Student ? Welcome Center for Guest Researchers and PhD Students

Students with special needs - Universität Regensburg

Students with special needs - Universität Regensburg Students with special needs - Universität Regensburg UR Home Students with Special Needs Students with special needs Are you affected by some sort of handicap or chronic illness? Then you are not alone with your needs. Approximately 7% of all students in Germany are affected by some sort of handicap or chronic illness. Who does the term ?student with special needs? apply to? This term applies to a relatively wide range of people, including students with sensory handicaps, i.e. the deaf, hard of hearing, blind or sight-impaired as well as students a limited ability to move their arms or legs, students with learning disabilities, i.e. dyslexia well as those with chronic physical or mental disorders. Students with special needs are entitled to diverse forms of assistance to provide all the support they need to help them successfully complete a university degree. At Universität Regensburg you will find two advisory services: Student Services offers an advisory service, as well as the university itself. Monika Jauch, Student Services, gives advice on financial aid and support during your studies as well as for everyday life how to get approval for technical and staff support how to interact with institutions and authorities how to receive support during critical and problematic personal situations social law and psychosocial questions The university's advisory service team (Stefanie Feuerer, Dr. Tina Plank, and Dr. Bernhard Pastötter) offers several services to support you during your studies, i.e. sight-impaired or blind students will find a scanner service, special computers and microscopes. A literature service helps you get books and other material from the library. Contact International Exchange Students If you come to Regensburg as an exchange student for a semester or two, you should contact Susanne Gschnaidner in the International Office for advice on how to prepare and organize your stay in Regensburg. Back to UR International Christine Betzner - 18.12.2013 09:28 UR International Students with Special Needs Advisory Services Advisory Services at the university and at student services back to "UR International"

Accommodation - Universität Regensburg Accommodation - Universität Regensburg UR Home Welcome Center News Advice and Checklists work-related Information for PhD Students Services on campus Living in Regensburg Accommodation Short-term housing Self-organised search Learning German Families Events Contact Accommodation The Welcome Center strives to help you find appropriate accommodation for your stay in Regensburg. On the one hand, the UR has a guest house ("Haus der Begegnung") available to international researchers. However, as there are only 14 flats, it is not always easy to make sure that one of them will be available for your stay. On the other hand, Ms. Strobl is in contact with many landlords that rent on the private housing market and cooperate on a regular basis with the UR to provide guests with, for the most part, furnished accommodation. IMPORTANT: Please ask your host to contact us, so that we can start with the accommodation search! Regretfully, we can only take accommodation petitions if they are directly endorsed by your host (more information for hosts - in German). You need to take into account, however, that living quarters in Regensburg have become very scarce. This means that we cannot guarantee to find accommodation that will fulfill your wishes. It is also important to bear in mind that the prices are not particularly inexpensive. We would like to remind you that you will need to register your address within the first seven days of your arrival or your move! Also important is the registration with the ?ARD ZDF Deutschlandradio Beitragsservice? for the Broadcasting Licence Fee, which has a monthly cost of ? 17.98 for each housing unit. More information about the Broadcasting Licence Fee The monthly cost of the German Broadcasting Licence Fee is currently ? 17.98 per household, regardless how many people live there and how many devices are capable of receiving radio and/or television signals. The fee is paid every three months. Normally, the tenant registers him or herself with the ?ARD ZDF Deutschlandradio Beitragsservice" and is responsible for paying the licence fee. The house or flat is rented as a flat-sharing community: the landlord can pay the licence fee and increase the rent for each tenant accordingly. This is useful either for short-term stays (a couple of months) or in the case of frequent change of tenants. For short-term stays in a hotel or holiday home, the licence fee is paid directly by the landlord. What is a flat? It is important to distinguish between: is the rented housing unit a separate flat or is it part of a flat-sharing community? A flat is (according to the definition of the ?ARD ZDF Beitragsservice?): a ?constructional self-contained unit, which is suitable and used for the purposes of living and/or sleeping, with its own entrance AND not accessible exclusively through another flat?. A flat-sharing community has a common (living) room, from which the individual rooms can be accessed. In the case you live in a flat-sharing community (or with your partner), only one of the tenants must pay the broadcasting fee (and the costs should be divided among all tenants). The decision of who should pay the fee must be taken by the tenants. We have put together an information sheet with the most important details of the Broadcasting Licence Fee. For more detailed information click here: www.rundfunkbeitrag.de. IMPORTANT: Not paying is considered an administrative offense and you will be required to pay a fine. Photos: Stefan Hanke Photography and Universität Regensburg Lorena Zander - 16.05.2014 12:12 HOMEPAGE UR Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and PhD Candidates EURAXESS Land of ideas Facts about Germany Charter for researchers Contact Information for hosts - in German

Accommodation - Universität Regensburg Accommodation - Universität Regensburg UR Home Welcome Center News Advice and Checklists work-related Information for PhD Students Services on campus Living in Regensburg Accommodation Short-term housing Self-organised search Learning German Families Events Contact Accommodation The Welcome Center strives to help you find appropriate accommodation for your stay in Regensburg. On the one hand, the UR has a guest house ("Haus der Begegnung") available to international researchers. However, as there are only 14 flats, it is not always easy to make sure that one of them will be available for your stay. On the other hand, Ms. Strobl is in contact with many landlords that rent on the private housing market and cooperate on a regular basis with the UR to provide guests with, for the most part, furnished accommodation. IMPORTANT: Please ask your host to contact us, so that we can start with the accommodation search! Regretfully, we can only take accommodation petitions if they are directly endorsed by your host (more information for hosts - in German). You need to take into account, however, that living quarters in Regensburg have become very scarce. This means that we cannot guarantee to find accommodation that will fulfill your wishes. It is also important to bear in mind that the prices are not particularly inexpensive. We would like to remind you that you will need to register your address within the first seven days of your arrival or your move! Also important is the registration with the ?ARD ZDF Deutschlandradio Beitragsservice? for the Broadcasting Licence Fee, which has a monthly cost of ? 17.98 for each housing unit. More information about the Broadcasting Licence Fee The monthly cost of the German Broadcasting Licence Fee is currently ? 17.98 per household, regardless how many people live there and how many devices are capable of receiving radio and/or television signals. The fee is paid every three months. Normally, the tenant registers him or herself with the ?ARD ZDF Deutschlandradio Beitragsservice" and is responsible for paying the licence fee. The house or flat is rented as a flat-sharing community: the landlord can pay the licence fee and increase the rent for each tenant accordingly. This is useful either for short-term stays (a couple of months) or in the case of frequent change of tenants. For short-term stays in a hotel or holiday home, the licence fee is paid directly by the landlord. What is a flat? It is important to distinguish between: is the rented housing unit a separate flat or is it part of a flat-sharing community? A flat is (according to the definition of the ?ARD ZDF Beitragsservice?): a ?constructional self-contained unit, which is suitable and used for the purposes of living and/or sleeping, with its own entrance AND not accessible exclusively through another flat?. A flat-sharing community has a common (living) room, from which the individual rooms can be accessed. In the case you live in a flat-sharing community (or with your partner), only one of the tenants must pay the broadcasting fee (and the costs should be divided among all tenants). The decision of who should pay the fee must be taken by the tenants. We have put together an information sheet with the most important details of the Broadcasting Licence Fee. For more detailed information click here: www.rundfunkbeitrag.de. IMPORTANT: Not paying is considered an administrative offense and you will be required to pay a fine. Self-organised accommodation search - Universität Regensburg Self-organised accommodation search - Universität Regensburg UR Home Welcome Center News Advice and Checklists work-related Information for PhD Students Services on campus Living in Regensburg Accommodation Short-term housing Self-organised search Learning German Families Events Contact Self-organised accommodation search If you do not wish to use the accommodation service of the Welcome Center or it is not possible to find an appropriate flat for you, you can search the private housing market. You will find very helpful sources of information in the following websites or in the classified ads printed by the local newspapers (also available online): Mittelbayerische Zeitung, the new classifeds appear both on Wednesdays and Saturdays Rundschau - Fridays (free-of-charge weekly newspaper that gets delivered to every household) Wochenblatt - Wednesdays (free-of-charge weekly newspaper) www.immobilienscout.de or www.immowelt.de Online-room search: http://www.stwno.de Mitwohnzentrale Regensburg: Alte Manggasse 1, 93047 Regensburg, Tel. 0941/378 20 24, e-mail: regensburg@mitwohnzentrale.de, Homepage: http://mitwohnzentrale-regensburg.de http://www.wg-gesucht.de http://www.studenten-wg.de http://www.zwischenmiete.de Please note that in Germany most flats are rented without furniture. This means that you should either bring furniture with you or you will have to buy it once you are here. It is often the case that the kitchen is already installed with all cupboards and appliances, but not always. Also important is that a deposit ("Provision") will be required (it can amount up to three months of the monthly rent). You will receive the deposit (plus interest) when you move out of the flat, as long as there have been no damages done to the flat. What do the abbreviations mean? Classified ads use many abbreviations, which are often difficult to understand. Here you will find a list of the most common ones: 2 Zi.Whg = two-room apartment 2 ZKB = two rooms, kitchen, bathroom zzgl. NK = additional (utilities: electricity/heating) costs EBK = fitted kitchen Blk = balcony ZH = central heating K = deposit NR = non-smoker KN = kitchenette NMM = rent per month (without costs for heating, gas, water, garbage disposal) MVZ = prepayment of the rent Prov. = commission WG = people sharing an apartment kalt = excluding heating costs Ablöse, Abstand = key money Where can you get second-hand furniture? At the "Werkhof" (Maintenance depot): Address: Auweg 22, 93055 Regensburg, Tel. 0941 / 59 99 818 Opening hours: Monday - Friday 9:00 pm - 5:30 pm, Saturday 10:00 pm - 2:00 pm At the Flea Market (Flohmarkt beim Recyclinghof): Markomannenstraße 3, 93053 Regensburg Opening hours: Tuesday - Friday 8:00 pm - 12:00 noon and 1:00 - 5:30 pm, Saturday 9 am -1 pm, Monday closed At the Flea Market (am Flohmarkt Klug) Heilliggeistgasse 20 93047 Regensburg Tel: 0941/56020 or 52185 Opening hours: Monday - Saturday 11:00 am - 8:00 pm Bulletin boards ("Schwarzes Brett") in buildings all over campus may display offers from private people. Bulletin boards at the entrance of some supermarkets. Photo: Regensburg Tourismus GmbH Lorena Zander - 10.12.2013 12:14 HOMEPAGE UR Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and PhD Candidates EURAXESS Land of ideas Facts about Germany Charter for researchers Contact Information for hosts - in German

Events - Universität Regensburg Events - Universität Regensburg UR Home Welcome Center News Advice and Checklists work-related Information for PhD Students Services on campus Living in Regensburg Accommodation Learning German Families Events Contact Events To help you meeting other international guests, the Welcome Center offers an array of events which are especially conceived for guest researchers and PhD candidates: reception for international researchers (Welcome Reception) excursions in Regensburg and its surroundings (incl. city and campus tours) Stammtisch / Get Togethers (once or twice a month) Friends International events You can download our program to get a first glance of the scheduled activities. Registration for events You can email us any time to sign up for the activities. You will often only hear back from us if there is not a space available. If you don't hear back right away, it means that your sign up was successful. Please note that some events have a maximum number of participants. Registration is first come, first serve. On the flip side, some events may be cancelled if there are not enough people who are interested. Email april.points@ur.de to sign up for activites and events or if you have questions. Feel free to email us at the Welcome Center any time if you notice that we don't have your proper contact information. Thursday, June 5, 2014 "Stammtisch" - monthly get together Joins us at a local downtown pub for an informal get-together. It's a time to get to know one another, share experiences, and establish interdisciplinary and international contacts and frienships. Time and location to be announced Friday, June 27, 2014 Summer party Friends International in cooperation with the Welcome Center cordially invites you to its summer party Where: Cafeteria in the chemistry department (weather permitting, we may be able to celebrate outdoors!) When: 6pm Saturday, July 12, 2014 Regensburg city tour in English Join us for a tour of the old city center of Regensburg. You will find out a lot about the enchanting buildings and interesting history. When: 10 am Price: to be announced Lorena Zander - 20.05.2014 09:34 HOMEPAGE UR Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and PhD Candidates EURAXESS Land of ideas Facts about Germany Charter for researchers Contact Information for hosts - in German

Families - Universität Regensburg Families - Universität Regensburg UR Home Welcome Center News Advice and Checklists work-related Information for PhD Students Services on campus Living in Regensburg Accommodation Learning German Families Partner's profession Family allowances Nurseries and schools Friends International Events Contact Families Are you considering to bring your family with you to Germany? What an adventure! The Welcome Center can offer you help and advice to make the move for you and your family as smooth as possible. Most likely you will have many questions at the beginning: How is child care organized? Which school should I register my child in? Which health insurance does my family need? Where can I find a big enough flat? And lots more. The UR is a family-friendly university with its own Family Service, which can offer you assistance with many of your questions. The city of Regensburg has published a very comprehensive Manual for Women (Frauenhandbuch) (in German), in which you will also find very valuable information. Child care during school vacation offered by FAMILY SERVICE For more information and sign up, please get in touch with the Welcome Center. Kids program at Köwe Handycrafts are offered every Saturday between 2:30 and 5 pm. All activities including child care are free of charge. For more information, click here. Lorena Zander - 16.05.2014 12:43 HOMEPAGE UR Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and PhD Candidates EURAXESS Land of ideas Facts about Germany Charter for researchers Contact Information for hosts - in German

Graduate School for East and Southeast European Studies - Universität Regensburg

Graduate School for East and Southeast European Studies - Universität Regensburg Graduate School for East and Southeast European Studies - Universität Regensburg UR Home Welcome Center News Advice and Checklists work-related Information for PhD Students Language skills Scholarships Graduate school Services on campus Living in Regensburg Accommodation Learning German Families Events Contact Graduate School for East and Southeast European Studies Located at Universität Regensburg and Ludwig-Maximilians Universität (LMU) Munich the Graduate School for East and Southeast European Studies (DFG Graduate School 1046) provides an excellent framework for innovative research projects investigating history, politics, law, language, culture, and the arts in Eastern and Southeastern Europe. The individual projects introduce new prospects for discussion and cooperation across the disciplines. In a ground-breaking approach the region is regarded in its interdependencies with other world regions, such as East Asia, Turkey, Western Europe, or North America, as East and Southeast European societies are strongly influenced by transregional relations such as migration, or the antagonism between "East" and "West" during the Cold War period. Vice versa, European history can only be fully understood if Eastern and Southeastern Europe are conceived as integral parts of European history. The curriculum is designed to support graduate students in their future career plans inside or outside academia, for example in national and international organizations or administration units, political consulting, media, cultural education, or the private sector. For further information: www.gs-oses.de (in German). Lorena Zander - 14.01.2014 09:17 HOMEPAGE UR Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and PhD Candidates EURAXESS Land of ideas Facts about Germany Charter for researchers Contact Information for hosts - in German

Language skills - Universität Regensburg Language skills - Universität Regensburg UR Home Welcome Center News Advice and Checklists work-related Information for PhD Students Language skills Scholarships Graduate school Services on campus Living in Regensburg Accommodation Learning German Families Events Contact Language skills If your intention is to write the doctoral thesis in German, you will need to pass the German test (DSH-Prüfung) before you enroll. It is required that you have proof of German language skills at B2 level. The German test (DSH-Prüfung) takes place at the UR normally at the end of March or at the end of September. NOTE: In case your doctoral thesis can be written in English, you ARE NOT required to have any German skills. The decision has to be expressly mentioned either in the regulations for doctoral studies of the respective faculty or in your letter of acceptance. Needless to say, basic or intermediary knowledge of the German language is extremely helpful for every day life. Where can I learn German? 1. No German knowledge or just basic skills Every semester the International Office strives to organize German beginner's courses especially for PhD candidates and Postdocs. Please ask the Welcome Center advisors for the current course offering. 2. German skills at intermediate or advanced level Especially for PhD candidates and guest researchers there is a small offer of German classes at intermediate and advance level. Please inquire about these courses at the Welcome Center. In addition, the UR offers German courses for students at intermediary and advanced levels, which are also open to PhD candidates. If you have already passed the German test (DSH-Prüfung) and want to improve your German skills further, you can sign up to the advanced German courses (Oberstufe). You may also register for German courses of the German as a Foreign Language department if you are not required to pass the German test, as long as there are free spots and you have the appropriate level. The courses offered at the UR take place during the day. Unfortunately there are no evening courses on campus. In case your research activity does not allow you to participate in the UR German courses, let us know. We can refer you to other valid options. Lorena Zander - 05.12.2013 11:40 HOMEPAGE UR Welcome Center for International Guest Researchers and PhD Candidates EURAXESS Land of ideas Facts about Germany Charter for researchers Contact Information for hosts - in German
